chunks.text: In the beginning God created the heauen and the earth. And the earth was without forme and void, and darkenesse was vpon the Then God said, Let there be light: And there was light. And God saw the light that it was good, and God separated the light from And God called the Light, Day, and the darkenes, he called Night. So the Againe God said, Let there be a firmament in the mids of the waters: and Then God made the firmament, and separated the waters, which were And God called the firmament Heauen. So the Euening and the morning God said againe, Let the waters vnder the heauen be gathered into one And God called the dry land, Earth, and he called the gathering together Then God said, Let the earth bud forth the bud of the herbe, that seedeth And the earth brought foorth the bud of the herbe, that seedeth seede So the euening and the morning were the third day. And God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the heauen, to And let them be for lights in the firmament of the heauen to giue light God then made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the And God set them in the firmament of the heauen, to shine vpon the And to rule in the day, and in the night, and to separate the light from the So the euening and the morning were the fourth day. Afterward God said, Let the waters bring foorth in abundance euery Then God created the great whales, and euery thing liuing and mouing, Then God blessed them, saying, Bring foorth fruite and multiplie, and So the euening and the morning were the fifte day. Moreouer God said, Let the earth bring foorth the liuing thing according And God made the beast of the earth according to his kinde, and the Furthermore God said, Let vs make man in our image according to our Thus God created the man in his image: in the image of God created he And God blessed them, and God said to them, Bring forth fruite and And God said, Beholde, I haue giuen vnto you euery herbe bearing Likewise to euery beast of the earth, and to euery foule of the heauen, And God sawe all that he had made, and loe, it was very good. So the

Thus the heauens and the earth were finished, and all the host of them. For in the seuenth day GOD ended his worke which he had made, and the So God blessed the seuenth day, and sanctified it, because that in it he had These are the generations of the heauens and of the earth, when they were And euery plant of the fielde, before it was in the earth, and euery herbe But a myst went vp from the earth, and watered all the earth. The Lord God also made the man of the dust of the grounde, and breathed And the Lord God planted a garden Eastward in Eden, and there he put (For out of the ground made the Lord God to grow euery tree pleasant to And out of Eden went a riuer to water the garden, and from thence it was The name of one is Pishon: the same compasseth the whole land of And the golde of that land is good: there is Bdelium, and the Onix stone. And the name of the seconde riuer is Gihon: the same compasseth the The name also of the third riuer is Hiddekel: this goeth toward the Then the Lord God tooke the man, and put him into the garden of Eden, And the Lord God commanded the man, saying, Thou shalt eate freely But of the tree of knowledge of good and euill, thou shalt not eate of it: Also the Lord God saide, It is not good that the man should be himself So the Lord God formed of the earth euery beast of the fielde, and euery The man therefore gaue names vnto all cattell, and to the foule of the Therefore the Lord God caused an heauie sleepe to fall vpon the man, And the ribbe which the Lord God had taken from the man, made he a Then the man said, This now is bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh. Therefore shall man leaue his father and his mother, and shall cleaue to And they were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.

Now the serpent was more subtill then any beast of the fielde, which the And the woman said vnto the serpent, We eate of the fruite of the trees of But of the fruite of the tree which is in the middes of the garden, God hath Then the serpent said to the woman, Ye shall not die at all, But God doeth knowe, that when ye shall eate thereof, your eyes shall be So the woman (seeing that the tree was good for meate, and that it was Then the eyes of them both were opened, and they knewe that they were Afterward they heard the voyce of the Lord God walking in the garden in But the Lord God called to the man, and said vnto him, Where art thou? Who saide, I heard thy voyce in the garden, and was afraide: because I And he saide, Who tolde thee, that thou wast naked? Hast thou eaten of Then the man saide, The woman which thou gauest to be with me, she And the Lord God saide to the woman, Why hast thou done this? And Then the Lord God said to the serpent, Because thou hast done this, thou I will also put enimitie betweene thee and the woman, and betweene thy Vnto the woman he said, I will greatly increase thy sorowes, and thy Also to Adam he said, Because thou hast obeyed the voyce of thy wife, Thornes also, and thistles shall it bring foorth to thee, and thou shalt eate In the sweate of thy face shalt thou eate bread, till thou returne to the (And the man called his wiues name Heuah, because she was the mother Vnto Adam also and to his wife did the Lord God make coates of And the Lord God said, Beholde, the man is become as one of vs, to Therefore the Lord God sent him foorth from the garden of Eden, to till Thus he cast out man, and at the East side of the garden of Eden he set

Afterward the man knew Heuah his wife, which conceiued and bare Kain, And againe she brought foorth his brother Habel, and Habel was a keeper And in processe of time it came to passe, that Kain brought an oblation And Habel also him selfe brought of the first fruites of his sheepe, and of But vnto Kain and to his offering he had no regarde: wherefore Kain was Then ye Lord said vnto Kain, Why art thou wroth? and why is thy If thou do well, shalt thou not be accepted? and if thou doest not well, Then Kain spake to Habel his brother. And when they were in the fielde, Then the Lord said vnto Kain, Where is Habel thy brother? Who Againe he said, What hast thou done? the voyce of thy brothers blood Now therefore thou art cursed from the earth, which hath opened her When thou shalt till the grounde, it shall not henceforth yeelde vnto thee Then Kain said to the Lord, My punishment is greater, then I can beare. Behold, thou hast cast me out this day from the earth, and from thy face Then the Lord said vnto him, Doubtlesse whosoeuer slayeth Kain, he Then Kain went out from the presence of the Lord, and dwelt in the land Kain also knewe his wife, which conceiued and bare Henoch: and he And to Henoch was borne Irad, and Irad begate Mehuiael, and Mehuiael And Lamech tooke him two wiues: the name of the one was Adah, and And Adah bare Iabal, who was the father of such as dwell in the tents, And his brothers name was Iubal, who was the father of all that play on And Zillah also bare Tubal-kain, who wrought cunningly euery craft of Then Lamech saide vnto his wiues Adah and Zillah, Heare my voyce, ye If Kain shalbe auenged seuen folde, truely Lamech, seuentie times seuen And Adam knewe his wife againe, and she bare a sonne, and she called And to ye same Sheth also there was borne a sonne, and he called his

This is the booke of the generations of Adam. In the day that God created Male and female created he them, and blessed them, and called their name Nowe Adam liued an hundred and thirtie yeeres, and begate a childe in And the dayes of Adam, after he had begotten Sheth, were eight hundreth So all the dayes that Adam liued, were nine hundreth and thirtie yeeres: And Sheth liued an hundreth and fiue yeeres, and begate Enosh. And Sheth liued, after he begate Enosh, eight hundreth and seuen yeeres, So all the dayes of Sheth were nine hundreth and twelue yeeres: and he Also Enosh liued ninetie yeeres, and begate Kenan. And Enosh liued, after he begate Kenan, eight hundreth and fifteene So all the dayes of Enosh were nine hundreth and fiue yeeres: and he Likewise Kenan liued seuentie yeeres, and begate Mahalaleel. And Kenan liued, after he begate Mahalaleel, eight hundreth and fourtie So all the dayes of Kenan were nine hundreth and tenne yeeres: and he Mahalaleel also liued sixtie and fiue yeres, and begate Iered. Also Mahalaleel liued, after he begate Iered, eight hundreth and thirtie So all the dayes of Mahalaleel were eight hundreth ninetie and fiue And Iered liued an hundreth sixtie and two yeeres, and begate Henoch. Then Iered liued, after he begate Henoch, eight hundreth yeeres, and So all the dayes of Iered were nine hundreth sixtie and two yeeres: and Also Henoch liued sixtie and fiue yeeres, and begate Methushelah. And Henoch walked with God, after he begate Methushelah, three So all the dayes of Henoch were three hundreth sixtie and fiue yeeres. And Henoch walked with God, and he was no more seene: for God Methushelah also liued an hundreth eightie and seuen yeeres, and begate And Methushelah liued, after he begate Lamech, seuen hundreth eightie So al the dayes of Methushelah were nine hundreth sixtie and nine Then Lamech liued an hundreth eightie and two yeeres, and begate a And called his name Noah, saying, This same shall comfort vs And Lamech liued, after he begate Noah, fiue hundreth ninetie and fiue So all the dayes of Lamech were seuen hundreth seuentie and seuen And Noah was fiue hundreth yeere olde. And Noah begate Shem, Ham

So when men began to be multiplied vpon the earth, and there were Then the sonnes of God sawe the daughters of men that they were faire, Therefore the Lord saide, My Spirit shall not alway striue with man, There were gyants in the earth in those dayes: yea, and after that the When the Lord sawe that the wickednesse of man was great in the earth, Then it repented ye Lord, that he had made man in the earth, and he was Therefore ye Lord said, I will destroy from the earth the man, whom I But Noah found grace in the eyes of the Lord. These are the generations of Noah. Noah was a iust and vpright man in And Noah begate three sonnes, Shem, Ham and Iapheth. The earth also was corrupt before God: for the earth was filled with Then God looked vpon the earth, and beholde, it was corrupt: for all And God said vnto Noah, An ende of all flesh is come before me: for the Make thee an Arke of pine trees: thou shalt make cabines in the Arke, And thus shalt thou make it: The length of the Arke shalbe three A windowe shalt thou make in the Arke, and in a cubite shalt thou finish And I, beholde, I will bring a flood of waters vpon the earth to destroy But with thee will I establish my couenant, and thou shalt goe into the And of euery liuing thing, of all flesh two of euery sort shalt thou cause Of the foules, after their kinde, and of the cattell after their kind, of And take thou with thee of all meate that is eaten: and thou shalt gather Noah therefore did according vnto all, that God commanded him: euen

And the Lord said vnto Noah, Enter thou and all thine house into the Of euery cleane beast thou shalt take to thee by seuens, the male and his Of the foules also of the heauen by seuens, male and female, to keepe For seuen dayes hence I will cause it raine vpon the earth fourtie dayes Noah therefore did according vnto all that the Lord commanded him. And Noah was sixe hundreth yeeres olde, when the flood of waters was So Noah entred and his sonnes, and his wife, and his sonnes wiues with Of the cleane beastes, and of the vncleane beastes, and of the foules, and There came two and two vnto Noah into the Arke, male and female, as And so after seuen dayes the waters of the flood were vpon the earth. In the sixe hundreth yeere of Noahs life in the second moneth, the And the raine was vpon the earth fourtie dayes and fourtie nightes. In the selfe same day entred Noah with Shem, and Ham and Iapheth, the They and euery beast after his kinde, and all cattell after their kinde, and For they came to Noah into ye Arke, two and two, of all flesh wherein is And they entring in, came male and female of all flesh, as God had Then ye flood was fourtie dayes vpon the earth, and the waters were The waters also waxed strong, and were increased exceedingly vpon the The waters preuailed so exceedingly vpon the earth, that all the high Fifteene cubites vpwarde did the waters preuaile, when the mountaines Then all flesh perished that moued vpon the earth, both foule and cattell Euery thing in whose nostrels the spirit of life did breathe, whatsoeuer So he destroyed euery thing that was vpon the earth, from man to beast, And the waters preuailed vpon the earth an hundreth and fiftie dayes.

Now God remembred Noah and euery beast, and all the cattell that was The fountaines also of the deepe and the windowes of heauen were And the waters returned from aboue the earth, going and returning: and And in the seuenth moneth, in the seuenteenth day of the moneth, the And the waters were going and decreasing vntill the tenth moneth: in the So after fourtie dayes, Noah opened the windowe of the Arke, which he And sent forth a rauen, which went out going forth and returning, vntill Againe he sent a doue from him, that he might see if the waters were But the doue found no rest for the sole of her foote: therefore she returned And he abode yet other seuen dayes, and againe he sent forth the doue And the doue came to him in ye euening, and loe, in her mouth was an Notwithstanding he wayted yet other seuen dayes, and sent forth the And in the sixe hundreth and one yeere, in the first day of the first And in the second moneth, in the seuen and twentieth day of the moneth Then God spake to Noah, saying, Goe forth of the Arke, thou and thy wife, and thy sonnes and thy sonnes Bring forth with thee euery beast that is with thee, of all flesh, both foule So Noah came forth, and his sonnes, and his wife, and his sonnes wiues Euery beast, euery creeping thing, and euery foule, all that moueth vpon Then Noah built an altar to the Lord and tooke of euery cleane beast, and And the Lord smellled a sauour of rest, and the Lord said in his heart, I Hereafter seede time and haruest, and colde and heate, and sommer and

And God blessed Noah and his sonnes, and said to them, Bring foorth Also the feare of you, and the dread of you shalbe vpon euery beast of the Euery thing that moueth and liueth, shall be meate for you: as the greene But flesh with the life thereof, I meane, with the blood thereof, shall ye For surely I will require your blood, wherein your liues are: at the hand of Who so sheadeth mans blood, by man shall his blood be shed: for in the But bring ye forth fruite and multiplie: grow plentifully in the earth, and God spake also to Noah and to his sonnes with him, saying, Behold, I, euen I establish my couenant with you, and with your seede And with euery liuing creature that is with you, with the foule, with the And my couenant will I establish with you, that from henceforth all flesh Then God saide, This is the token of the couenant which I make I haue set my bowe in the cloude, and it shalbe for a signe of the And when I shall couer the earth with a cloud, and the bowe shall be Then will I remember my couenant, which is betweene me and you, and Therefore the bowe shalbe in the cloude, that I may see it, and remember God said yet to Noah, This is the signe of the couenant, which I haue Nowe the sonnes of Noah going foorth of the Arke, were Shem and Ham These are the three sonnes of Noah, and of them was the whole earth Noah also began to be an husband man and planted a vineyard. And he drunke of ye wine and was drunken, and was vncouered in the And when Ham the father of Canaan sawe the nakednesse of his father, Then tooke Shem and Iapheth a garment, and put it vpon both their Then Noah awoke from his wine, and knew what his yonger sonne had And said, Cursed be Canaan: a seruant of seruants shall he be vnto his He said moreouer, blessed be the Lord God of Shem, and let Canaan be God perswade Iapheth, that he may dwell in the tentes of Shem, and let And Noah liued after the flood three hundreth and fiftie yeeres. So all the dayes of Noah were nine hundreth and fiftie yeeres: and he

Now these are the generations of the sonnes of Noah, Shem, Ham and The sonnes of Iapheth were Gomer and Magog, and Madai, and Iauan, And the sonnes of Gomer, Ashkenaz, and Riphath, and Togarmah. Also the sonnes of Iauan, Elishah and Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim. Of these were the yles of the Gentiles deuided in their landes, euery man Moreouer, ye sonnes of Ham were Cush, and Mizraim, and Put, and And the sonnes of Cush, Seba and Hauilah, and Sabtah, and Raamah, and And Cush begate Nimrod, who began to be mightie in the earth. He was a mightie hunter before the Lord. wherefore it is saide, As And the beginning of his kingdome was Babel, and Erech, and Accad, Out of that land came Asshur, and builded Niniueh, and the citie Resen also betweene Niniueh and Calah: this is a great citie. And Mizraim begate Ludim, and Anamim, and Lehabim, and Pathrusim also, and Casluhim (out of whom came the Philistims) and Also Canaan begat Zidon his first borne, and Heth, And Iebusi, and Emori, and Girgashi, And Hiui, and Arki, and Sini, And Aruadi, and Zemari, and Hamathi: and afterwarde were the families Then the border of the Canaanites was from Zidon, as thou commest to These are the sonnes of Ham according to their families, according to Vnto Shem also the father of all the sonnes of Eber, and elder brother of The sonnes of Shem were Elam and Asshur, and Arpachshad, and Lud, And the sonnes of Aram, Vz and Hul, and Gether and Mash. Also Arpachshad begate Shelah, and Shelah begate Eber. Vnto Eber also were borne two sonnes: the name of the one was Peleg: Then Ioktan begate Almodad and Sheleph, and Hazarmaueth, and Ierah, And Hadoram, and Vzal, and Dicklah, And Obal, and Abimael, and Sheba, And Ophir, and Hauilah, and Iobab: all these were the sonnes of Ioktan. And their dwelling was from Mesha, as thou goest vnto Sephar a mount These are the sonnes of Shem according to their families, according to These are the families of the sonnes of Noah, after their generations

Then the whole earth was of one language and one speache. And as they went from the East, they found a plaine in the land of Shinar, And they said one to another, Come, let vs make bricke, and burne it in Also they said, Goe to, let vs builde vs a citie and a towre, whose top may But the Lord came downe, to see the citie and towre, which the sonnes of And the Lord said, Beholde, the people is one, and they all haue one Come on, let vs goe downe, and there confound their language, that euery So ye Lord scattered them from thence vpon all the earth, and they left off Therefore the name of it was called Babel, because the Lord did there These are the generations of Shem: Shem was an hundreth yeere olde, And Shem liued, after he begate Arpachshad, fiue hundreth yeeres, and Also Arpachshad liued fiue and thirtie yeeres, and begate Shelah. And Arpachshad liued, after he begate Shelah, foure hundreth and three And Shelah liued thirtie yeeres, and begat Eber. So Shelah liued, after he begat Eber, foure hundreth and three yeeres, Likewise Eber liued foure and thirtie yeres, and begate Peleg. So Eber liued, after he begate Peleg, foure hundreth and thirtie yeeres, And Peleg liued thirtie yeeres, and begate Reu. And Peleg liued, after he begate Reu, two hundreth and nine yeeres, and Also Reu liued two and thirtie yeeres, and begate Serug. So Reu liued, after he begate Serug, two hundreth and seuen yeeres, and Moreouer Serug liued thirtie yeeres, and begate Nahor. And Serug liued, after he begate Nahor, two hundreth yeeres, and begate And Nahor liued nine and twentie yeeres, and begate Terah. So Nahor liued, after he begate Terah, an hundreth and nineteene yeeres, So Terah liued seuentie yeeres, and begate Abram, Nahor, and Haran. Nowe these are the generations of Terah: Terah begate Abram, Nahor, Then Haran died before Terah his father in the land of his natiuitie, in Vr So Abram and Nahor tooke them wiues. The name of Abrams wife was But Sarai was barren, and had no childe. Then Terah tooke Abram his sonne, and Lot the sonne of Haran, his So the dayes of Terah were two hundreth and fiue yeeres, and Terah died

For the Lord had said vnto Abram, Get thee out of thy countrey, and from And I will make of thee a great nation, and will blesse thee, and make thy I will also blesse them that blesse thee, and curse them that curse thee, So Abram departed, euen as ye Lord spake vnto him, and Lot went with Then Abram tooke Sarai his wife, and Lot his brothers sonne, and all their So Abram passed through the land vnto the place of Shechem, and vnto And the Lord appeared vnto Abram, and said, Vnto thy seede will I giue Afterward remouing thence vnto a moutaine Eastward from Beth-el, he Againe Abram went forth going and iourneying toward the South. Then there came a famine in the land: therefore Abram went downe into And when he drewe neere to enter into Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife, Therefore it will come to passe, that when the Egyptians see thee, they Say, I pray thee, that thou art my sister, that I may fare well for thy sake, Nowe when Abram was come into Egypt, the Egyptians behelde the And the Princes of Pharaoh sawe her, and commended her vnto Pharaoh: Who intreated Abram well for her sake, and he had sheepe, and beeues, But the Lord plagued Pharaoh and his house with great plagues, because Then Pharaoh called Abram, and saide, Why hast thou done this vnto Why saidest thou, She is my sister, that I should take her to be my wife? And Pharaoh gaue men commandement concerning him: and they

Then Abram went vp from Egypt, he, and his wife, and all that he had, And Abram was very rich in cattell, in siluer and in golde. And he went on his iourney from ye South toward Beth-el, to the place Vnto the place of the altar, which he had made there at the first: and there And Lot also, who went with Abram, had sheepe, and cattell and tentes, So that the land coulde not beare them, that they might dwell together: for Also there was debate betweene ye heardmen of Abrams cattell, and the Then saide Abram vnto Lot, Let there be no strife, I pray thee, betweene Is not the whole land before thee? depart I pray thee from me: if thou wilt So when Lot lifted vp his eyes, he saw that all the plaine of Iorden was Then Lot chose vnto him all the plaine of Iorden, and tooke his iourney Abram dwelled in the lande of Canaan, and Lot abode in the cities of the Now the men of Sodom were wicked and exceeding sinners against the Then the Lord saide vnto Abram, (after that Lot was departed from him) For all the land, which thou seest, will I giue vnto thee and to thy seede And I will make thy seede, as the dust of the earth: so that if a man can Arise, walke through the land, in ye length thereof, and breadth thereof: Then Abram remoued his tent, and came and dwelled in the plaine of

And in the dayes of Amraphel King of Shinar, Arioch King of Ellasar, These men made warre with Bera King of Sodom, and with Birsha King All these ioyned together in the vale of Siddim, which is the salt Sea. Twelue yeere were they subiect to Chedor-laomer, but in the thirteenth And in the fourteenth yeere came Chedor-laomer, and the Kings that were And the Horites in their mount Seir, vnto the plaine of Paran, which is by And they returned and came to En-mishpat, which is Kadesh, and smote Then went out the King of Sodom, and the King of Gomorah, and the To wit, with Chedor-laomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations, and Now the vale of Siddim was full of slime pits, and the Kings of Sodom Then they tooke all the substance of Sodom and Gomorah, and al their They tooke Lot also Abrams brothers sonne and his substance (for he Then came one that had escaped, and told Abram the Ebrew, which When Abram heard that his brother was taken, he brought forth of them Then he, and his seruants deuided them selues against them by night, And he recouered all the substance, and also brought againe his brother After that he returned from the slaughter of Chedor-laomer, and of the And Melchi-zedek King of Shalem brought foorth bread and wine: and Therefore he blessed him, saying, Blessed art thou, Abram, of God most And blessed be the most high God, which hath deliuered thine enemies Then the King of Sodom saide to Abram, Giue me the persons, and take And Abram said to the King of Sodom, I haue lift vp mine hand vnto the That I will not take of all that is thine, so much as a threde or Saue onely that, which the yong men haue eaten, and the partes of the

After these things, the worde of the Lord came vnto Abram in a vision, And Abram said, O Lord God, what wilt thou giue me, seeing I goe Againe Abram saide, Beholde, to me thou hast giuen no seede: wherefore Then beholde, the worde of the Lord came vnto him, saying, This man Moreouer he brought him forth and said, Looke vp nowe vnto heauen, And Abram beleeued the Lord, and he counted that to him for Againe he saide vnto him, I am the Lord, that brought thee out of Vr of And he said, O Lord God, whereby shall I knowe that I shall inherite it? Then he said vnto him, Take me an heifer of three yeeres olde, and a shee So he tooke all these vnto him, and deuided them into the middes, and Then foules fell on the carkases, and Abram droue them away. And when the sunne went downe, there fell an heauie sleepe vpon Then he saide to Abram, Knowe for a suretie, that thy seede shalbe a Notwithstanding the nation, whom they shall serue, will I iudge: and But thou shalt goe vnto thy fathers in peace, and shalt be buried in a And in the fourth generation they shall come hither againe: for the Also when the sunne went downe, there was a darkenes: and behold, a In that same day the Lord made a couenant with Abram, saying, Vnto The Kenites, and the Kenizites, and the Kadmonites, And the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Rephaims, The Amorites also, and the Canaanites, and the Girgashites, and the

Loe, mine eye hath seene all this: mine eare hath heard, and vnderstande I knowe also as much as you knowe: I am not inferiour vnto you. But I will speake to the Almightie, and I desire to dispute with God. For in deede ye forge lyes, and all you are physitions of no value. Oh, that you woulde holde your tongue, that it might be imputed to you Nowe heare my disputation, and giue eare to the arguments of my lips. Will ye speake wickedly for Gods defence, and talke deceitfully for his Will ye accept his person? or will ye contende for God? Is it well that he shoulde seeke of you? will you make a lye for him, as He will surely reprooue you, if ye doe secretly accept any person. Shall not his excellencie make you afraid? and his feare fall vpon you? Are not his dayes determined? the nober of his moneths are with thee: Turne from him that he may cease vntill his desired day, as an hyreling. But man is sicke, and dyeth, and man perisheth, and where is he? Bvt Iob answered, and sayd, Heare diligently my wordes, and this shalbe in stead of your consolations. Suffer mee, that I may speake, and when I haue spoken, mocke on. Doe I direct my talke to man? If it were so, how should not my spirit be Marke mee, and be abashed, and lay your hand vpon your mouth. Euen when I remember, I am afrayde, and feare taketh hold on my flesh. Their seede is established in their sight with them, and their generation Their houses are peaceable without feare, and the rod of God is not vpon Their bullocke gendreth, and fayleth not: their cow calueth, and casteth They send forth their children like sheepe, and their sonnes dance. They take the tabret and harpe, and reioyce in the sound of the organs. One dyeth in his full strength, being in all ease and prosperitie. His breasts are full of milke, and his bones runne full of marowe. Bvt Iob answered, and sayde, Whom helpest thou? him that hath no power? sauest thou the arme that Whome counsellest thou? him that hath no wisedome? thou shewest right To whom doest thou declare these words? or whose spirit commeth out of The dead things are formed vnder the waters, and neere vnto them. The siluer surely hath his veyne, and ye gold his place, where they take it. Yron is taken out of the dust, and brasse is molten out of the stone. So Iob proceeded and continued his parable, saying, Oh that I were as in times past, when God preserued me! When his light shined vpon mine head: and when by his light I walked As I was in the dayes of my youth: when Gods prouidence was vpon my When the almightie was yet with me, and my children round about me. When I washed my pathes with butter, and when the rocke powred me out When I went out to the gate, euen to the iudgement seat, and when I The yong men saw me, and hid themselues, and the aged arose, and stood The princes stayed talke, and layde their hand on their mouth. The voyce of princes was hidde, and their tongue cleaued to the roofe of And when the eare heard me, it blessed me: and when the eye sawe me, For I deliuered the poore that cryed, and the fatherlesse, and him that The blessing of him that was ready to perish, came vpon me, and I I put on iustice, and it couered me: my iudgement was as a robe, and a I was the eyes to the blinde, and I was the feete to the lame. I was a father vnto the poore, and when I knewe not the cause, I sought it I brake also the chawes of the vnrighteous man, and pluckt the praye out Then I sayde, I shall die in my nest, and I shall multiplie my dayes as the For my roote is spread out by the water, and the dewe shall lye vpon my My glory shall renue towarde me, and my bowe shall be restored in mine Vnto me men gaue eare, and wayted, and helde their tongue at my After my wordes they replied not, and my talke dropped vpon them. Bvt now they that are yonger then I, mocke me: yea, they whose fathers I For whereto shoulde the strength of their handes haue serued mee, seeing For pouertie and famine they were solitary, fleeing into the wildernes, They cut vp nettels by the bushes, and the iuniper rootes was their meate. They were chased forth from among men: they shouted at them, as at a Therfore they dwelt in the clefts of riuers, in the holes of the earth and They roared among the bushes, and vnder the thistles they gathered They were the children of fooles and the children of villaines, which were And now am I their song, and I am their talke. They abhorre me, and flee farre from mee, and spare not to spit in my Because that God hath loosed my corde and humbled mee, they haue The youth rise vp at my right hand: they haue pusht my feete, and haue They haue destroyed my paths: they tooke pleasure at my calamitie, they They came as a great breach of waters, and vnder this calamitie they Feare is turned vpon mee: and they pursue my soule as the winde, and Therefore my soule is nowe powred out vpon me, and the dayes of It pearceth my bones in the night, and my sinewes take no rest. For the great vehemencie is my garment changed, which compasseth me He hath cast me into the myre, and I am become like ashes and dust. Whe I cry vnto thee, thou doest not heare me, neither regardest me, Thou turnest thy selfe cruelly against me, and art enemie vnto mee with Thou takest me vp and causest mee to ride vpon the winde, and makest Surely I knowe that thou wilt bring mee to death, and to the house Doubtles none can stretch his hand vnto the graue, though they cry in his Did not I weepe with him that was in trouble? was not my soule in Yet when I looked for good, euill came vnto me: and when I waited for My bowels did boyle without rest: for the dayes of affliction are come I went mourning without sunne: I stood vp in the congregation and I am a brother to the dragons, and a companion to the ostriches. My skinne is blacke vpon me, and my bones are burnt with heate. Therefore mine harpe is turned to mourning, and mine organs into the

I made a couenant with mine eyes: why then should I thinke on a mayde? For what portion should I haue of God from aboue? and what inheritance Is not destruction to the wicked and strange punishment to the workers of Doeth not he beholde my wayes and tell all my steps? If I haue walked in vanitie, or if my foote hath made haste to deceite, Let God weigh me in the iust balance, and he shall know mine vprightnes. If my steppe hath turned out of the way, or mine heart hath walked after Let me sowe, and let another eate: yea, let my plantes be rooted out. If mine heart hath bene deceiued by a woman, or if I haue layde wayte at Let my wife grinde vnto another man, and let other men bow downe For this is a wickednes, and iniquitie to bee condemned: Yea, this is a fire that shall deuoure to destruction, and which shall roote If I did contemne the iudgement of my seruant, and of my mayde, when What then shall I do when God standeth vp? and when he shall visit me, He that hath made me in the wombe, hath he not made him? hath not he If I restrained the poore of their desire, or haue caused the eyes of the Or haue eaten my morsels alone, and the fatherles hath not eaten thereof, (For from my youth hee hath growen vp with me as with a father, and If I haue seene any perish for want of clothing, or any poore without If his loynes haue not blessed me, because he was warmed with the If I haue lift vp mine hande against the fatherlesse, when I saw that I Let mine arme fal from my shoulder, and mine arme be broken from the For Gods punishment was fearefull vnto me, and I could not be If I made gold mine hope, or haue sayd to the wedge of golde, Thou art If I reioyced because my substance was great, or because mine hand had If I did behold the sunne, when it shined, or the moone, walking in her If mine heart did flatter me in secrete, or if my mouth did kisse mine (This also had bene an iniquitie to be condemned: for I had denied the If I reioyced at his destruction that hated me, or was mooued to ioye Neither haue I suffred my mouth to sinne, by wishing a curse vnto his Did not the men of my Tabernacle say, Who shall giue vs of his flesh? The stranger did not lodge in the streete, but I opened my doores vnto If I haue hid my sinne, as Adam, concealing mine iniquitie in my Though I could haue made afraid a great multitude, yet the most Oh that I had some to heare me! beholde my signe that the Almightie Woulde not I take it vpon my shoulder, and binde it as a crowne vnto I will tell him the nomber of my goings, and goe vnto him as to a prince. If my lande cry against me, or the furrowes thereof complayne together, If I haue eaten the fruites thereof without siluer: or if I haue grieued the Let thistles growe in steade of wheate, and cockle in the stead of Barley.

So these three men ceased to answere Iob, because he esteemed himselfe Then the wrath of Elihu the sonne of Barachel the Buzite, of the familie Also his anger was kindled against his three friends, because they could (Now Elihu had wayted til Iob had spoken: for they were more ancient in So when Elihu saw, that there was none answere in the mouth of the three Therefore Elihu the sonne of Barachel, the Buzite answered, and sayd, I For I said, The dayes shall speake, and the multitude of yeeres shall teach Surely there is a spirite in man, but the inspiration of the Almightie giueth Great men are not alway wise, neither doe the aged alway vnderstand Therefore I say, Heare me, and I will shew also mine opinion. Behold, I did waite vpon your wordes, and hearkened vnto your Yea, when I had considered you, lo, there was none of you that reproued Lest ye should say, We haue found wisedome: for God hath cast him Yet hath he not directed his words to me, neyther will I answere him by Then they fearing, answered no more, but left off their talke. When I had wayted (for they spake not, but stood still and answered no Then answered I in my turne, and I shewed mine opinion. For I am full of matter, and the spirite within me compelleth me. Beholde, my belly is as the wine, which hath no vent, and like the new Therefore will I speake, that I may take breath: I will open my lippes, I will not now accept the person of man, neyther will I giue titles to man. For I may not giue titles, lest my Maker should take me away suddenly.

Wherefore, Iob, I pray thee, heare my talke and hearken vnto all my Beholde now, I haue opened my mouth: my tongue hath spoken in my My words are in the vprightnesse of mine heart, and my lippes shall The Spirite of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almightie hath If thou canst giue me answere, prepare thy selfe and stand before me. Beholde, I am according to thy wish in Gods stead: I am also formed of Beholde, my terrour shall not feare thee, neither shall mine hand be Doubtles thou hast spoken in mine eares, and I haue heard the voyce of I am cleane, without sinne: I am innocent, and there is none iniquitie in Lo, he hath found occasions against me, and counted me for his enemie. He hath put my feete in the stockes, and looketh narrowly vnto all my Behold, in this hast thou not done right: I will answere thee, that God is Why doest thou striue against him? for he doeth not giue account of all For God speaketh once or twise, and one seeth it not. In dreames and visions of the night, when sleepe falleth vpon men, and Then he openeth the eares of men, euen by their corrections, which he That he might cause man to turne away from his enterprise, and that he And keepe backe his soule from the pit, and that his life should not passe He is also striken with sorow vpon his bed, and the griefe of his bones is So that his life causeth him to abhorre bread, and his soule daintie meate. His flesh faileth that it can not be seene, and his bones which were not So his soule draweth to the graue, and his life to the buriers. If there be a messenger with him, or an interpreter, one of a thousand to Then will he haue mercie vpon him, and will say, Deliuer him, that he go Then shall his flesh be as fresh as a childes, and shall returne as in the He shall pray vnto God, and he will be fauourable vnto him, and he shall He looketh vpon men, and if one say, I haue sinned, and peruerted He will deliuer his soule from going into the pit, and his life shall see the Lo, all these things will God worke twise or thrise with a man, That he may turne backe his soule from the pit, to be illuminate in the Marke well, O Iob, and heare me: keepe silence, and I will speake. If there be matter, answere me, and speak: for I desire to iustifie thee. If thou hast not, heare me: holde thy tongue, and I will teach thee

Moreouer Elihu answered, and saide, Heare my wordes, ye wise men, and hearken vnto me, ye that haue For the eare tryeth the words, as the mouth tasteth meate. Let vs seeke iudgement among vs, and let vs knowe among our selues For Iob hath saide, I am righteous, and God hath taken away my Should I lye in my right? my wound of the arrowe is grieuous without my What man is like Iob, that drinketh scornfulnesse like water? Which goeth in the companie of them that worke iniquitie, and walketh For he hath saide, It profiteth a man nothing that he should walke with Therefore hearken vnto me, ye men of wisedome, God forbid that For he will render vnto man according to his worke, and cause euery one And certainely God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almightie Whome hath he appointed ouer the earth beside him selfe? or who hath If he set his heart vpon man, and gather vnto him selfe his spirit and his All flesh shall perish together, and man shall returne vnto dust. And if thou hast vnderstanding, heare this and hearken to the voyce of Shal he that hateth iudgement, gouerne? and wilt thou iudge him wicked Wilt thou say vnto a King, Thou art wicked? or to princes, Ye are How much lesse to him that accepteth not the persons of princes, and They shall die suddenly, and the people shalbe troubled at midnight, and For his eyes are vpon the wayes of man, and he seeth all his goings. There is no darkenesse nor shadowe of death, that the workers of For he will not lay on man so much, that he should enter into iudgement He shall breake the mightie without seeking, and shall set vp other in Therefore shall he declare their works: he shall turne the night, and they He striketh them as wicked men in the places of the seers, Because they haue turned backe from him, and would not consider all So that they haue caused the voyce of the poore to come vnto him, and And when he giueth quietnesse, who can make trouble? and when he Because the hypocrite doeth reigne, and because the people are snared. Surely it appertaineth vnto God to say, I haue pardoned, I will not But if I see not, teach thou me: if I haue done wickedly, I will doe no Wil he performe the thing through thee? for thou hast reproued it, Let men of vnderstanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken vnto me. Iob hath not spoken of knowledge, neyther were his wordes according to I desire that Iob may be tryed, vnto the ende touching the answeres for For he addeth rebellion vnto his sinne: he clappeth his handes among vs,

Elihu spake moreouer, and said, Thinkest thou this right, that thou hast said, I am more righteous then For thou hast said, What profiteth it thee and what auaileth it me, to purge Therefore will I answere thee, and thy companions with thee. Looke vnto the heauen, and see and behold the cloudes which are hyer If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him, yea, when thy sinnes be If thou be righteous, what giuest thou vnto him? or what receiueth he at Thy wickednesse may hurt a man as thou art: and thy righteousnes may They cause many that are oppressed, to crye, which crye out for ye But none saieth, Where is God that made me, which giueth songs in the Which teacheth vs more then the beastes of the earth, and giueth vs more Then they crye because of the violence of the wicked, but he answereth Surely God will not heare vanitie, neyther will the Almightie regard it. Although thou sayest to God, Thou wilt not regard it, yet iudgement is But nowe because his anger hath not visited, nor called to count the euill Therfore Iob openeth his mouth in vaine, and multiplieth wordes without

Elihu also proceeded and sayde, Suffer me a litle, and I will instruct thee: for I haue yet to speake on Gods I will fetche my knowledge afarre off, and will attribute righteousnes vnto For truely my wordes shall not be false, and he that is perfect in Behold, the mighty God casteth away none that is mighty and valiant of He mainteineth not the wicked, but he giueth iudgement to the afflicted. He withdraweth not his eyes from the righteous, but they are with Kings And if they bee bound in fetters and tyed with the cordes of affliction, Then will he shewe them their worke and their sinnes, because they haue He openeth also their eare to discipline, and commandeth them that they If they obey and serue him, they shall end their dayes in prosperity, and But if they wil not obey, they shall passe by the sworde, and perish But the hypocrites of heart increase the wrath: for they call not when he Their soule dyeth in youth, and their life among the whoremongers. He deliuereth the poore in his affliction, and openeth their eare in Euen so woulde he haue taken thee out of the streight place into a broade But thou art ful of the iudgement of the wicked, though iudgement and For Gods wrath is, least hee should take that away in thine abundance: Wil he regard thy riches? he regardeth not golde, nor all them that excel Be not carefull in the night, howe he destroyeth the people out of their Take thou heede: looke not to iniquitie: for thou hast chosen it rather Beholde, God exalteth by his power: what teacher is like him? Who hath appointed to him his way? or who can say, Thou hast done Remember that thou magnifie his worke, which men behold. All men see it, and men beholde it afarre off. Beholde, God is excellent, and we knowe him not, neither can the When he restraineth the droppes of water, the rayne powreth down by Which raine the cloudes do droppe and let fall abundantly vpon man. Who can know the diuisions of ye clouds and the thunders of his Beholde, he spreadeth his light vpon it, and couereth the bottome of the For thereby hee iudgeth the people, and giueth meate abundantly. He couereth the light with the clouds, and commandeth them to go His companion sheweth him thereof, and there is anger in rising vp.

At this also mine heart is astonied, and is mooued out of his place. Heare the sound of his voyce, and the noyse that goeth out of his mouth. He directeth it vnder the whole heauen, and his light vnto the endes of the After it a noyse soundeth: hee thundereth with the voyce of his maiestie, God thundereth marueilously with his voyce: he worketh great things, For he sayth to the snowe, Be thou vpon the earth: likewise to the small With the force thereof he shutteth vp euery man, that all men may knowe Then the beastes go into the denne, and remaine in their places. The whirlewind commeth out of the South, and the colde from the North At the breath of God the frost is giuen, and the breadth of the waters is He maketh also the cloudes to labour, to water the earth, and scattereth And it is turned about by his gouernment, that they may doe whatsoeuer Whether it be for punishment, or for his lande, or of mercie, he causeth it Hearken vnto this, O Iob: stand and consider the wonderous workes of Diddest thou knowe when God disposed them? and caused the light of Hast thou knowen the varietie of the cloude, and the wonderous workes Or howe thy clothes are warme, when he maketh the earth quiet through Hast thou stretched out the heaues, which are strong, and as a molten Tell vs what we shall say vnto him: for we can not dispose our matter Shall it be told him when I speake? or shall man speake when he shalbe And nowe men see not the light, which shineth in the cloudes, but the The brightnesse commeth out of the North: the praise thereof is to God, It is the Almightie: we can not finde him out: he is excellent in power Let men therefore feare him: for he will not regarde any that are wise in

Then answered the Lord vnto Iob out of the whirle winde, and said, Who is this that darkeneth the counsell by wordes without knowledge? Girde vp nowe thy loynes like a man: I will demande of thee and declare Where wast thou when I layd the foundations of the earth? declare, if thou Who hath layde the measures thereof, if thou knowest, or who hath Whereupon are the foundations thereof set: or who layed the corner stone When the starres of the morning praysed me together, and all the children Or who hath shut vp the Sea with doores, when it yssued and came foorth When I made the cloudes as a couering thereof, and darkenesse as the When I stablished my commandement vpon it, and set barres and And said, Hitherto shalt thou come, but no farther, and here shall it stay Hast thou commanded the morning since thy dayes? hast thou caused the That it might take hold of the corners of the earth, and that the wicked It is turned as clay to facion, and all stand vp as a garment. And from the wicked their light shall be taken away, and the hie arme Hast thou entred into the bottomes of the sea? or hast thou walked to Haue the gates of death bene opened vnto thee? or hast thou seene the Hast thou perceiued the breadth of the earth? tell if thou knowest all this. Where is the way where light dwelleth? and where is the place of That thou shouldest receiue it in the boundes thereof, and that thou Knewest thou it, because thou wast then borne, and because the nomber Hast thou entred into the treasures of the snow? or hast thou seene the Which I haue hid against the time of trouble, against the day of warre By what way is the light parted, which scattereth the East winde vpon Who hath deuided the spowtes for the raine? or the way for the lightning To cause it to raine on the earth where no man is, and in the wildernes To fulfil the wilde and waste place, and to cause the bud of the herbe to Who is the father of the rayne? or who hath begotten the droppes of the Out of whose wombe came the yee? who hath ingendred the frost of the The waters are hid as with a stone: and the face of the depth is frosen. Canst thou restraine the sweete influences of the Pleiades? or loose the Canst thou bring foorth Mazzaroth in their time? canst thou also guide Knowest thou the course of heauen, or canst thou set the rule thereof in Canst thou lift vp thy voice to the cloudes that the aboundance of water Canst thou sende the lightenings that they may walke, and say vnto thee, Who hath put wisedome in the reines? or who hath giuen the heart Who can nomber cloudes by wisedome? or who can cause to cease the When the earth groweth into hardnesse, and the clottes are fast together?

Wilt thou hunt the pray for the lyon? or fill the appetite of the lyons When they couch in their places, and remaine in the couert to lye in Who prepareth for the rauen his meate, when his birdes crie vnto God, Knowest thou the time when the wilde goates bring foorth yong? or doest Canst thou nomber the moneths that they fulfill? or knowest thou the time They bow them selues: they bruise their yong and cast out their sorowes. Yet their yong waxe fatte, and growe vp with corne: they goe foorth and Who hath set the wilde asse at libertie? or who hath loosed the bondes of It is I which haue made the wildernesse his house, and the salt places his He derideth the multitude of the citie: he heareth not the crie of the He seeketh out the mountaine for his pasture, and searcheth after euery Will the vnicorne serue thee? or will he tary by thy cribbe? A Psalme of Dauid, when he fled from his sonne Absalom. Lord, howe Many say to my soule, There is no helpe for him in God. Selah. But thou Lord art a buckler for me: my glory, and the lifter vp of mine I did call vnto the Lord with my voyce, and he heard me out of his holy I layed me downe and slept, and rose vp againe: for the Lord susteined I will not be afrayde for ten thousand of the people, that should beset me O Lord, arise: helpe me, my God: for thou hast smitten all mine enemies Saluation belongeth vnto the Lord, and thy blessing is vpon thy people.

Looke vpon mine affliction and my trauel, and forgiue all my sinnes. Deliuer Israel, O God, out of all his troubles.

Praise ye the Lord with me, and let vs magnifie his Name together. The lyons doe lacke and suffer hunger, but they, which seeke the Lord, Come children, hearken vnto me: I will teache you the feare of the Lord. What man is he, that desireth life, and loueth long dayes for to see good? Keepe thy tongue from euill, and thy lips, that they speake no guile. Eschewe euill and doe good: seeke peace and follow after it. A Psalme of Dauid for remembrance. O Lord, rebuke mee not in thine For thine arrowes haue light vpon me, and thine hand lyeth vpon me. I am weakened and sore broken: I roare for the very griefe of mine heart. When I declare my paine, and am sory for my sinne, Then mine enemies are aliue and are mightie, and they that hate me They also, that rewarde euill for good, are mine aduersaries, because I Forsake me not, O Lord: be not thou farre from me, my God. Haste thee to helpe mee, O my Lord, my saluation.

To him that excelleth. A Psalme to give instruction, committed to the Howe thou hast driuen out the heathen with thine hand, and planted them: For they inherited not the lande by their owne sworde, neither did their Thou art my King, O God: send helpe vnto Iaakob. Through thee haue we thrust backe our aduersaries: by thy Name haue we For I do not trust in my bowe, neither can my sworde saue me. But thou hast saued vs from our aduersaries, and hast put them to Therefore will wee praise God continually, and will confesse thy Name But now thou art farre off, and puttest vs to confusion, and goest not forth Thou makest vs to turne backe from the aduersary, and they, which hate Thou giuest vs as sheepe to bee eaten, and doest scatter vs among the Thou sellest thy people without gaine, and doest not increase their price. Thou makest vs a reproche to our neighbours, a iest and a laughing Thou makest vs a prouerbe among the nations, and a nodding of the head My confusion is dayly before me, and the shame of my face hath For the voyce of the slaunderer and rebuker, for the enemie and auenger. All this is come vpon vs, yet doe wee not forget thee, neither deale wee Our heart is not turned backe: neither our steps gone out of thy paths, Albeit thou hast smitten vs downe into the place of dragons, and couered If wee haue forgotten the Name of our God, and holden vp our hands to Shall not God searche this out? for hee knoweth the secrets of the heart. Surely for thy sake are we slaine continually, and are counted as sheepe Vp, why sleepest thou, O Lord? awake, be not farre off for euer. Wherefore hidest thou thy face? and forgettest our miserie and our For our soule is beaten downe vnto the dust: our belly cleaueth vnto the Rise vp for our succour, and redeeme vs for thy mercies sake.

Selah. Come, and behold the workes of the Lord, what desolations he hath made He maketh warres to cease vnto the endes of the world: he breaketh the Be still and knowe that I am God: I will be exalted among the heathen, The Lord of hostes is with vs: the God of Iaakob is our refuge. Selah.

I am become a stranger vnto my brethren, euen an aliant vnto my mothers For the zeale of thine house hath eaten mee, and the rebukes of them that I wept and my soule fasted, but that was to my reproofe. I put on a sacke also: and I became a prouerbe vnto them. They that sate in the gate, spake of mee, and the drunkards sang of me. A Psalme committed to Asaph. Yet God is good to Israel: euen, to the As for me, my feete were almost gone: my steps had well neere slipt. For I feared at the foolish, when I sawe the prosperitie of the wicked. For there are no bandes in their death, but they are lustie and strong. They are not in trouble as other men, neither are they plagued with other Therefore pride is as a chayne vnto them, and crueltie couereth them as a Their eyes stande out for fatnesse: they haue more then heart can wish. They are licentious, and speake wickedly of their oppression: they talke They set their mouth against heauen, and their tongue walketh through the Therefore his people turne hither: for waters of a full cup are wrung out And they say, Howe doeth God know it? or is there knowledge in the Lo, these are the wicked, yet prosper they alway, and increase in riches. Certainely I haue clensed mine heart in vaine, and washed mine hands in For dayly haue I bene punished, and chastened euery morning. If I say, I will iudge thus, beholde the generation of thy children: I haue Then thought I to know this, but it was too painefull for me, Vntill I went into the Sanctuarie of God: then vnderstoode I their ende. Surely thou hast set them in slipperie places, and castest them downe How suddenly are they destroyed, perished and horribly consumed, As a dreame when one awaketh! O Lord, when thou raisest vs vp, thou Certainely mine heart was vexed, and I was pricked in my reines: So foolish was I and ignorant: I was a beast before thee. Yet I was alway with thee: thou hast holden me by my right hand. Thou wilt guide me by thy counsell, and afterward receiue me to glory. Whom haue I in heauen but thee? and I haue desired none in the earth My flesh fayleth and mine heart also: but God is the strength of mine For loe, they that withdrawe themselues from thee, shall perish: thou As for me, it is good for me to draw neere to God: therefore I haue put

To him that excelleth. Destroy not. A Psalme or song committed toAsaph. When I shall take a conuenient time, I will iudge righteously. The earth and all the inhabitantes thereof are dissolued: but I will I saide vnto the foolish, Be not so foolish, and to the wicked, Lift not vp Lift not vp your horne on high, neither speake with a stiffe necke. For to come to preferment is neither from the East, nor from the West, nor But God is the iudge: he maketh lowe and he maketh hie. For in the hand of the Lord is a cup, and the wine is red: it is full mixt, But I will declare for euer, and sing prayses vnto the God of Iaakob. A Psalme to give instruction committed to Asaph. Heare my doctrine, O I will open my mouth in a parable: I will declare high sentences of olde. Which we haue heard and knowen, and our fathers haue tolde vs. Wee will not hide them from their children but to the generation to come How he established a testimonie in Iaakob, and ordeined a Law in Israel, That the posteritie might knowe it, and the children, which should be That they might set their hope on God, and not forget the workes of God And not to bee as their fathers, a disobedient and rebellious generation: a The children of Ephraim being armed and shooting with the bowe, turned They kept not the couenant of God, but refused to walke in his Lawe, And forgate his Actes, and his wonderfull woorkes that he had shewed Hee did marueilous thinges in the sight of their fathers in the lande of He deuided the Sea, and led them through: he made also the waters to In the day time also hee led them with a cloude, and all the night with a He claue the rockes in the wildernes, and gaue them drinke as of the He brought floods also out of the stonie rocke; so that hee made the Yet they sinned stil against him, and prouoked the Highest in the And tempted God in their heartes in requiring meate for their lust. They spake against God also, saying, Can God prepare a table in the Behold, he smote the rocke, that the water gushed out, and the streames Therefore the Lord heard and was angrie, and the fire was kindled in Because they beleeued not in God, and trusted not in his helpe. To him that excelleth upon Gittith. A Psalme committed to Asaph. Sing Take the song and bring forth the timbrel, the pleasant harpe with the Blowe the trumpet in the newe moone, euen in the time appointed, at our For this is a statute for Israel, and a Law of the God of Iaakob. A Psalme committed to Aspah. God standeth in the assemblie of gods: How long wil ye iudge vniustly, and accept the persons of the wicked? Doe right to the poore and fatherlesse: doe iustice to the poore and needie. Deliuer the poore and needie: saue them from the hand of the wicked. They knowe not and vnderstand nothing: they walke in darkenes, albeit I haue said, Ye are gods, and ye all are children of the most High. But ye shall die as a man, and yee princes, shall fall like others. O God, arise, therefore iudge thou the earth: for thou shalt inherite all

For a day in thy courtes is better then a thousand other where: I had For the Lord God is the sunne and shielde vnto vs: the Lord will giue O Lord of hostes, blessed is the man that trusteth in thee.

To him that excelleth. A Psalme committed to the sonnes of Korah. Lord, Thou hast forgiuen the iniquitie of thy people, and couered all their Thou hast withdrawen all thine anger, and hast turned backe from the Turne vs, O God of our saluation, and release thine anger toward vs. Wilt thou be angry with vs for euer? and wilt thou prolong thy wrath from Wilt thou not turne againe and quicken vs, that thy people may reioyce in Shew vs thy mercie, O Lord, and graunt vs thy saluation. I will hearken what the Lord God will say: for he will speake peace vnto Surely his saluation is neere to them that feare him, that glory may dwell Mercie and trueth shall meete: righteousnes and peace shall kisse one Trueth shall bud out of the earth, and righteousnes shall looke downe Yea, the Lord shall giue good things, and our land shall giue her Righteousnesse shall go before him, and shall set her steps in the way.

Thou hast set vp the right hand of his enemies, and made all his Thou hast also turned the edge of his sworde, and hast not made him to Thou hast caused his dignitie to decay, and cast his throne to the ground. The dayes of his youth hast thou shortned, and couered him with shame. Lord, howe long wilt thou hide thy selfe, for euer? shall thy wrath burne Remember of what time I am: wherefore shouldest thou create in vaine What man liueth, and shall not see death? shall hee deliuer his soule Lord, where are thy former mercies, which thou swarest vnto Dauid in Remember, O Lord, the rebuke of thy seruants, which I beare in my For thine enemies haue reproched thee, O Lord, because they haue Praised be the Lord for euermore. So be it, euen so be it.

A prayer of Moses, the man of God. Thou hast set our iniquities before thee, and our secret sinnes in the light For all our dayes are past in thine anger: we haue spent our yeeres as a The time of our life is threescore yeeres and ten, and if they be of Who knoweth the power of thy wrath? for according to thy feare is thine Teach vs so to nomber our dayes, that we may apply our heartes vnto Returne (O Lord, howe long?) and be pacified toward thy seruants. Fill vs with thy mercie in the morning: so shall we reioyce and be glad Comfort vs according to the dayes that thou hast afflicted vs, and Let thy worke bee seene towarde thy seruants, and thy glory vpon their And let the beautie of the Lord our God be vpon vs, and direct thou the

Who so dwelleth in the secrete of the most High, shall abide in the I will say vnto the Lord, O mine hope, and my fortresse: he is my God, in Surely he will deliuer thee from the snare of the hunter, and from the Hee will couer thee vnder his winges, and thou shalt be sure vnder his Thou shalt not be afraide of the feare of the night, nor of the arrowe that Nor of the pestilence that walketh in the darkenesse: nor of the plague that A thousand shall fall at thy side, and tenne thousand at thy right hand, but Doubtlesse with thine eyes shalt thou beholde and see the reward of the For thou hast said, The Lord is mine hope: thou hast set the most High for There shall none euill come vnto thee, neither shall any plague come For hee shall giue his Angels charge ouer thee to keepe thee in all thy They shall beare thee in their handes, that thou hurt not thy foote against Thou shalt walke vpon the lyon and aspe: the yong lyon and the dragon Because he hath loued me, therefore will I deliuer him: I will exalt him He shall call vpon me, and I wil heare him: I will be with him in trouble: With long life wil I satisfie him, and shew him my saluation.

The Lord reigneth, and is clothed with maiestie: the Lord is clothed, and Thy throne is established of olde: thou art from euerlasting. The floodes haue lifted vp, O Lord: the floodes haue lifted vp their voyce: The waues of ye sea are marueilous through the noyse of many waters, Thy testimonies are very sure: holinesse becommeth thine House, O Lord,

O Lord God the auenger, O God the auenger, shewe thy selfe clearely. Exalt thy selfe, O Iudge of the worlde, and render a reward to the proude. Lord how long shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked triumph? They prate and speake fiercely: all the workers of iniquitie vaunt They smite downe thy people, O Lord, and trouble thine heritage. They slay the widowe and the stranger, and murder the fatherlesse. Yet they say, The Lord shall not see: neither will the God of Iaakob regard Vnderstande ye vnwise among the people: and ye fooles, when will ye be Hee that planted the eare, shall hee not heare? or he that formed the eye, Or he that chastiseth the nations, shall he not correct? hee that teacheth The Lord knoweth the thoughtes of man, that they are vanitie. Blessed is the man, whom thou chastisest, O Lord, and teachest him in That thou mayest giue him rest from the dayes of euill, whiles the pitte is Surely the Lord will not faile his people, neither will he forsake his For iudgement shall returne to iustice, and all the vpright in heart shall Who will rise vp with me against the wicked? or who will take my part If the Lord had not holpen me, my soule had almost dwelt in silence. Praise ye the Lord of lordes: for his mercie endureth for euer: Which onely doeth great wonders: for his mercie endureth for euer: Which by his wisedome made the heauens: for his mercie endureth for Which hath stretched out the earth vpon the waters: for his mercie Which made great lightes: for his mercie endureth for euer: As the sunne to rule the day: for his mercie endureth for euer: The moone and the starres to gouerne the night: for his mercie endureth Which smote Egypt with their first borne, (for his mercie endureth for And brought out Israel from among them (for his mercie endureth for With a mightie hande and stretched out arme: for his mercie endureth for Which deuided the red Sea in two partes: for his mercie endureth for And made Israel to passe through the mids of it: for his mercie endureth And ouerthrewe Pharaoh and his hoste in the red Sea: for his mercie Which led his people through the wildernes: for his mercie endureth for Which smote great Kings: for his mercie endureth for euer: And slewe mightie Kings: for his mercie endureth for euer: As Sihon King of the Amorites: for his mercie endureth for euer: And Og the King of Bashan: for his mercie endureth for euer: And gaue their land for an heritage: for his mercie endureth for euer: Euen an heritage vnto Israel his seruant: for his mercie endureth for euer: Which remembred vs in our base estate: for his mercie endureth for euer: And hath rescued vs from our oppressours: for his mercie endureth for Which giueth foode to all flesh: for his mercie endureth for euer. Praise ye the God of heauen: for his mercie endureth for euer.

If I forget thee, O Ierusalem, let my right hand forget to play. A Psalme of David of Praise. O my God and King, I will extold thee, and I will blesse thee dayly, and prayse thy Name for euer and euer. Great is the Lord, and most worthy to be praysed, and his greatnes is Generation shall praise thy works vnto generation, and declare thy power. The Lord is good to all, and his mercies are ouer all his workes. All thy workes prayse thee, O Lord, and thy Saints blesse thee. They shewe the glory of thy kingdome, and speake of thy power, To cause his power to be knowen to the sonnes of men, and the glorious Thy kingdome is an euerlasting kingdome, and thy dominion endureth The Lord vpholdeth all that fall, and lifteth vp all that are ready to fall. The eyes of all waite vpon thee, and thou giuest them their meate in due Thou openest thine hand, and fillest all things liuing of thy good The Lord is righteous in all his wayes, and holy in all his workes. The wordes of the Preacher, the sonne of Dauid King in Ierusalem. Vanitie of vanities, sayth the Preacher: vanitie of vanities, all is vanitie. I am the man, that hath seene affliction in the rod of his indignation. He hath ledde mee, and brought me into darkenes, but not to light. Surely he is turned against me: he turneth his hand against me all the day. My flesh and my skinne hath he caused to waxe olde, and he hath broken He hath builded against me, and compassed me with gall, and labour. He hath set me in darke places, as they that be dead for euer. He hath hedged about mee, that I cannot get out: he hath made my Also when I cry and showte, hee shutteth out my prayer. He hath stopped vp my wayes with hewen stone, and turned away my He was vnto me as a beare lying in waite, and as a Lion in secret places. He hath stopped my wayes, and pulled me in pieces: he hath made me He hath bent his bow and made me a marke for the arrow. Hee caused the arrowes of his quiuer to enter into my reines. I was a derision to all my people, and their song all the day. He hath filled me with bitternes, and made me drunken with He hath also broken my teeth with stones, and hath couered me with Thus my soule was farre off from peace: I forgate prosperitie, And I saide, My strength and mine hope is perished from the Lord, Remembring mine affliction, and my mourning, the wormewood and the My soule hath them in remembrance, and is humbled in me. I consider this in mine heart: therefore haue I hope. It is the Lordes mercies that wee are not consumed, because his They are renued euery morning: great is thy faithfulnesse. The Lord is my portion, sayth my soule: therefore wil I hope in him. The Lord is good vnto them, that trust in him, and to the soule that It is good both to trust, and to waite for the saluation of the Lord. It is good for a man that he beare the yoke in his youth. He sitteth alone, and keepeth silence, because he hath borne it vpon him. He putteth his mouth in the dust, if there may be hope. Hee giueth his cheeke to him that smiteth him: he is filled full with For the Lord will not forsake for euer. But though he sende affliction, yet will he haue compassion according to For he doeth not punish willingly, nor afflict the children of men, In stamping vnder his feete all the prisoners of the earth, In ouerthrowing the right of a man before the face of the most high, In subuerting a man in his cause: the Lord seeth it not. Who is he then that sayth, and it commeth to passe, and the Lord Out of the mouth of the most high proceedeth not euill and good? Wherefore then is the liuing man sorowfull? man suffreth for his sinne. Let vs search and try our wayes, and turne againe to the Lord. Let vs lift vp our hearts with our handes vnto God in the heauens. We haue sinned, and haue rebelled, therefore thou hast not spared. Thou hast couered vs with wrath, and persecuted vs: thou hast slaine and Thou hast couered thy selfe with a cloude, that our prayer should not Thou hast made vs as the ofscouring and refuse in the middes of the All our enemies haue opened their mouth against vs. Feare, and a snare is come vpon vs with desolation and destruction. Mine eye casteth out riuers of water, for the destruction of the daughter Mine eye droppeth without stay and ceaseth not, Till the Lord looke downe, and beholde from heauen. Mine eye breaketh mine heart because of all the daughters of my citie. Mine enemies chased me sore like a birde, without cause. They haue shut vp my life in the dungeon, and cast a stone vpon me. Waters flowed ouer mine head, then thought I, I am destroyed. I called vpon thy Name, O Lord, out of the lowe dungeon. Thou hast heard my voyce: stoppe not thine eare from my sigh and from Thou drewest neere in the day that I called vpon thee: thou saydest, O Lord, thou hast maintained the cause of my soule, and hast redeemed O Lord, thou hast seene my wrong, iudge thou my cause. Thou hast seene all their vengeance, and all their deuises against me. Thou hast heard their reproch, O Lord, and all their imaginations against The lippes also of those that rose against me, and their whispering Behold, their sitting downe and their rising vp, how I am their song. Giue them a recompence, O Lord, according to the worke of their Giue them sorow of heart, euen thy curse to them. Persecute with wrath and destroy them from vnder the heauen, O Lord.

Remember, O Lord, what is come vpon vs: consider, and behold our Our inheritance is turned to the strangers, our houses to the aliants. We are fatherles, euen without father, and our mothers are as widowes. Wee haue drunke our water for money, and our wood is solde vnto vs. Our neckes are vnder persecution: we are wearie, and haue no rest. We haue giuen our handes to the Egyptians, and to Asshur, to be satisfied Our fathers haue sinned, and are not, and we haue borne their iniquities. Seruants haue ruled ouer vs, none would deliuer vs out of their hands. Wee gate our bread with the perill of our liues, because of the sword of Our skinne was blacke like as an ouen because of the terrible famine. They defiled the women in Zion, and the maydes in the cities of Iudah. The princes are hanged vp by their hande: the faces of the elders were They tooke the yong men to grinde, and the children fell vnder the The Elders haue ceased from the gate and the yong men from their The ioy of our heart is gone, our daunce is turned into mourning. The crowne of our head is fallen: wo nowe vnto vs, that we haue sinned. Therefore our heart is heauy for these things, our eyes are dimme, Because of the mountaine of Zion which is desolate: the foxes runne But thou, O Lord, remainest for euer: thy throne is from generation to Wherefore doest thou forget vs for euer, and forsake vs so long time? Turne thou vs vnto thee, O Lord, and we shalbe turned: renue our dayes But thou hast vtterly reiected vs: thou art exceedingly angry against vs.

Take heede that ye giue not your almes before men, to be seene of them, Therefore when thou giuest thine almes, thou shalt not make a trumpet to But when thou doest thine almes, let not thy left hand knowe what thy That thine almes may be in secret, and thy Father that seeth in secret, hee And when thou prayest, be not as the hypocrites: for they loue to stand, But when thou prayest, enter into thy chamber and when thou hast shut Also when ye pray, vse no vaine repetitions as the Heathen: for they Be ye not like them therefore: for your Father knoweth whereof ye haue After this maner therefore pray ye, Our father which art in heauen, Thy Kingdome come. Thy will be done euen in earth, as it is in heauen. Giue vs this day our dayly bread. And forgiue vs our dettes, as we also forgiue our detters. And leade vs not into tentation, but deliuer vs from euill: for thine is the For if ye doe forgiue men their trespasses, your heauenly Father will also But if ye do not forgiue men their trespasses,, no more will your father Moreouer, when ye fast, looke not sowre as the hypocrites: for they But when thou fastest, anoint thine head, and wash thy face, That thou seeme not vnto men to fast, but vnto thy Father which is in Lay not vp treasures for your selues vpon the earth, where the mothe and But lay vp treasures for your selues in heauen, where neither the mothe For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also. The light of the body is the eye: if then thine eye be single, thy whole But if thine eye be wicked, then all thy body shalbe darke. Wherefore if No man can serue two masters: for eyther he shall hate the one, and loue Therefore I say vnto you, be not carefull for your life, what ye shall eate, Behold the foules of the heauen: for they sowe not, neither reape, nor Which of you by taking care is able to adde one cubite vnto his stature? And why care ye for raiment? Learne howe the lilies of the fielde doe Yet I say vnto you, that euen Salomon in all his glorie was not arayed Wherefore if God so clothe the grasse of the fielde which is to day, and Therefore take no thought, saying, What shall we eate? or what shall we (For after all these things seeke the Gentiles) for your heauenly Father But seeke ye first the kingdome of God, and his righteousnesse, and all Care not then for the morowe: for the morowe shall care for it selfe: the

Judge not, that ye be not iudged. Eor with what iudgement ye iudge, ye shall be iudged, and with what And why seest thou the mote, that is in thy brothers eye, and perceiuest Or howe sayest thou to thy brother, Suffer me to cast out the mote out of Hypocrite, first cast out that beame out of thine owne eye, and then shalt Giue ye not that which is holy, to dogges, neither cast ye your pearles Aske, and it shall be giuen you: seeke, and ye shall finde: knocke, and it For whosoeuer asketh, receiueth: and he, that seeketh, findeth: and to him For what man is there among you, which if his sonne aske him bread, Or if he aske fish, wil he giue him a serpent? If ye then, which are euill, can giue to your children good giftes, howe Therefore whatsoeuer ye woulde that men should doe to you, euen so Enter in at the streight gate: for it is the wide gate, and broade way that Because the gate is streight, and the way narowe that leadeth vnto life, Beware of false prophets, which come to you, in sheepes clothing, but Ye shall know them by their fruites. Doe men gather grapes of thornes? So euery good tree bringeth foorth good fruite, and a corrupt tree A good tree can not bring forth euil fruite: neither can a corrupt tree Euery tree that bringeth not forth good fruite, is hewen downe, and cast Therefore by their fruites ye shall knowe them. Not euery one that sayeth vnto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the Many will say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, haue we not by thy Name And then will I professe to them, I neuer knewe you: depart from me, ye Whosoeuer then heareth of mee these words, and doeth the same, I will And the raine fell, and the floods came, and the windes blewe, and beat But whosoeuer heareth these my wordes, and doeth them not, shall be And the raine fell, and the floods came, and the windes blewe, and beat And it came to passe, when Iesus had ended these wordes, the people For he taught them as one hauing authoritie, and not as the Scribes.
